definition.title: What is Content Repurposing?
definition.content: Content repurposing is taking one piece of content and adapting it for multiple platforms and formats. It's not duplicating—it's transforming the same core message into format-native content that performs well on each platform.

landingContent.formula: [SOURCE CONTENT] → [EXTRACT KEY POINTS] → [ADAPT FOR PLATFORM] → [OPTIMIZE FORMAT] = Multiplied Content
tips: Start with long-form - it's easier to break down than build up; podcasts and blogs make great source material
Extract 3-5 key insights - each insight can become its own piece of content
Adapt, don't copy - each platform has different norms; LinkedIn isn't Twitter isn't Instagram
Create a content calendar - plan which piece goes where and when for maximum impact

faq.question: What content can I repurpose?
faq.answer: Blog posts, podcast transcripts, video scripts, webinar recordings, long-form articles, and presentations all work great.

faq.question: What formats can I create?
faq.answer: Twitter/X threads, LinkedIn posts, Instagram carousels, email newsletters, YouTube descriptions, and summary articles.

faq.question: Does this count as duplicate content?
faq.answer: No, each platform version is rewritten for that format. It's the same message, delivered differently for each audience.

faq.question: How many pieces can I create from one source?
faq.answer: Typically 5-10 pieces from a single blog post or podcast episode. Create a whole week of content from one piece.
